articles.headline: Patient Data Posted Online in Major Breach of Privacy
articles.snippet: A breach involving a California hospital led to the public posting of medical records for 20,000 emergency room patients on a commercial Web site for nearly a year.
articles.abstract: A breach involving a California hospital led to the public posting of medical records for 20,000 emergency room patients on a commercial Web site for nearly a year.
articles.lead_paragraph: A medical privacy breach led to the public posting on a commercial Web site of data for 20,000 emergency room patients at Stanford Hospital in Palo Alto, Calif., including names and diagnosis codes, the hospital has confirmed. The information stayed online for nearly a year.

articles.headline: Obama Challenges Congress on Job Plan
articles.snippet: President Obama challenged lawmakers in a blunt address to enact a sweeping package of tax cuts and new spending designed to revive the stagnant job market.
articles.abstract: President Obama challenged lawmakers in a blunt address to enact a sweeping package of tax cuts and new spending designed to revive the stagnant job market.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Mixing politically moderate proposals with a punchy tone, President Obama challenged lawmakers on Thursday to “pass this jobs bill” — a blunt call on Congress to enact his $447 billion package of tax cuts and new government spending, designed to revive a stalling economy and his own political standing.

articles.headline: Wal-Mart to Bring Back Layaway for Holidays
articles.snippet: Following some rivals, Wal-Mart will set aside products for delayed purchase, a sign of the financial pressures on shoppers.
articles.abstract: Following some rivals, Wal-Mart will set aside products for delayed purchase, a sign of the financial pressures on shoppers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wal-Mart said on Thursday that it planned to bring back its layaway payment plan for the holidays, an indication that shoppers at the nation’s largest retailer were feeling more and more strapped.

articles.headline: Fed Chief Describes Consumers as Too Bleak
articles.snippet: “Even taking into account the many financial pressures that they face, households seem exceptionally cautious,” said Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman.
articles.abstract: “Even taking into account the many financial pressures that they face, households seem exceptionally cautious,” said Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, offered a new twist on a familiar subject Thursday, revisiting the question of why growth continues to fall short of hopes and expectations.

articles.headline: Many Views on a Greek Bond’s Value
articles.snippet: The audit firms of Italian, British and French banks are signing off on wildly different ways of scrutinizing the same underlying market for Greek bonds.
articles.abstract: The audit firms of Italian, British and French banks are signing off on wildly different ways of scrutinizing the same underlying market for Greek bonds.
articles.lead_paragraph: Is there one set of international accounting standards, or can each country choose its own when the going gets tough?

articles.headline: Feasting on Paperwork
articles.snippet: A year after Congress passed the broadest financial overhaul since the Great Depression, the Dodd-Frank Act has spawned a host of new businesses to help Wall Street comply.
articles.abstract: A year after Congress passed the broadest financial overhaul since the Great Depression, the Dodd-Frank Act has spawned a host of new businesses to help Wall Street comply.
articles.lead_paragraph: The amount billed by Debevoise & Plimpton to write a 17-page letter on a new rule intended to rein in risky banking — around $100,000 — would make most authors jealous.

articles.headline: A Bipartisan Move to Tackle Benefits Programs
articles.snippet: Republicans and Democrats are no longer fighting over whether to tackle the popular entitlement programs — Medicare, Medicaid and Social Security — but how to do it.
articles.abstract: Republicans and Democrats are no longer fighting over whether to tackle the popular entitlement programs — Medicare, Medicaid and Social Security — but how to do it.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a significant shift driven by bipartisan concern about the looming long-term debt, Republicans and Democrats are no longer fighting over whether to tackle the popular entitlement programs — Medicare, Medicaid and Social Security — but over how to do it.
articles.byline: By Jackie Calmes and Robert Pear

articles.headline: A Setback for the Euro Zone
articles.snippet: The departure of Jürgen Stark, described as the European Central Bank’s chief economist, brought the discord over the response to Europe’s sovereign debt crisis into full view.
articles.abstract: The departure of Jürgen Stark, described as the European Central Bank’s chief economist, brought the discord over the response to Europe’s sovereign debt crisis into full view.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Discord over the handling of Europe’s debt crisis spilled into full view on Friday when an influential member of the European Central Bank’s executive board unexpectedly resigned. The news intensified fears over the euro currency union’s ability to cooperatively resolve its problems.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing and Nicholas Kulish

articles.headline: Europe Is Urged to Take Bolder Action on Debt
articles.snippet: Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner warned that headwinds from Europe’s deepening debt crisis risked exacerbating problems in the United States.
articles.abstract: Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner warned that headwinds from Europe’s deepening debt crisis risked exacerbating problems in the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: MARSEILLE, France — If anyone was counting on finance officials of the powerful Group of 7 nations to help map a way out of Europe’s debt crisis and calm the markets, consider this: the G-7 met on Friday, the crisis grew worse and the markets plummeted.
